Colleagues, at this time we will open the remote public comment period for items on the city council agenda, introduction and referral calendar, and work program.

Public comment system.

I will moderate the public comment period today.
We will have a public comment period for this meeting to last a total of 20 minutes.
Each Speaker is going to have two minutes to address the city council.
Speakers are asked--speakers are called upon in the order in which they registered to provide public comment on the Website.

Each Speaker must call in from the phone number used for this registration and using the meeting phone number, i.d., and Passcode that was Emailed to each Speaker upon confirmation of their Preregistration.

For those individuals who do show up as not present, I'll make sure to call your name out to make sure that you have notice of the fact that you are listed as not present so you can check your credentials once again.

Again, I'll call on each Speaker by name and the order in which they registered if you have not yet registered to speak but would like to, you can sign up before the end of public comment by going to the Website.
The public comment link is also listed on today's agenda.

Good afternoon.
District 7 Commenting on continuing failure to have police accountability in Seattle.
This Friday, in four days we commemorate the fourth anniversary of the SPD's brutal murder of Charlena wiles, who was pregnant leaving her four children Motherless.
At a public meeting after this murder, Councilmember Juarez said quote, we will demand accountability, transparency and community oversight and not allow this to happen.
Council President Gonzalez said quote, I want you to hold us accountable.
We can't wait any longer for these systems to be changed.
Unquote.
Councilmember Herbold said that quote, we are already shamed.
What I am pledging to you is to work on finding a new way of doing things so that we can actually get different results.
I will use the power that I have on the city Council to change what is happening today in our city.
Unquote.
, the following years brought us the brutal SPD killings of several more people.

Not only had nothing changed, but the families and loved ones of those killed by the SPD had to suffer, in addition to a brutal and unjust laws, a complete failure of accountability and justice because their loved ones were killed in Seattle were truly independent investigations have been on possible.
Seattle's police accountability system deemed all these killings either lawful and proper, or have not even completed or attempted an investigation.

A recent NBC news report on officers who have repeatedly shot people focuses on one Seattle law officer who shot four people, killing three, including the horrifying and completely affordable murder of Ryan Smith in 2019.
It is only to 100% civilian led and run accountability that these acts can be revealed thereby presenting future once.
I invite everyone here to join Seattleites in a city initiative to finally create full civilian oversight of police by going to Seattle's Top.Org thank you.

Hi.
I'm a resident of district 4. I am representing the organization Decriminalize nature Seattle.
The lowest law enforcement priorities with protections from medical practitioners.
I would first like to thank the seven Seattle city council members for their signatures last week on the letter submitted by Councilmembers Lewis and Herbold.
There is increasingly more recognition that the schedule one designations of Psychedelic medicine is based in archaic misinformation.
The examination and inclusion of these medicines in the task force is an extremely welcome change.
We find these substances are incredibly valid during the treatment of pathological and psychological reporters.
They carry low to no risk of addiction and abuse, but are actually beneficial in treating the abuse of other substances such as alcohol and opiates.
Based on pulmonary evidence, they even exceed the success rates of Twelve-Step programs.

In addition, we would ask the Council to signal their support by taking the very modest steps of making enforcement of drug laws related to them the lowest law enforcement priority as soon as possible.

If the city of Seattle passes our measure, we would be the eighth city in the country to acknowledge the benefits of these substances and send a signal that people are ready for more comprehensive legal change.
Thank you.
Thank you so much for calling in today.
Next up is Sage Wilson, followed by Raymond Evans.
Sage Wilson on behalf of working Washington today to urge you to pass the contractor transparency ordinance today.
Including the intention by Council to act to make the Seattle gig economy pay A. the Covid crisis has become a Covid bonanza.
Instacart added more than half 1 million new workers.
Gig companies have established new lines of business.
Dozens of executives have struck it rich.
In fact, door dash's Ceo was paid $400 million last year, one of the various types passes on record.
The people doing the work are paid as little as two dollars a job.
Too many workers can't afford good themselves.
City Council took bold and effective action last year to pass emergency hazard pay and sick pay.
These laws have made a tremendous difference.

However, as we look to the possibility of these emergency laws expiring, it's time to take the next step and act to advance from the policies that raise pay, protect possibility, and provide meaningful transparency to all gig workers.
The Timeline for action is an important step in that action.
As we work with Stakeholders to hammer out a policy that RAISES pay, we welcome the clear statement to end what is sub so you.
Including people of color, immigrant workers, workers with disabilities, Lgbtq workers and other marginalized workers.
The Council is also taking action today on a permanent policy to address some of the concerns raised with community restaurants.
We appreciate council as a Multifaceted approach.
We are glad to city council is taking steps to address the needs of gig workers.
Thank you again for your work on the transparency ordinance before you today.
I look forward to it passing.
Thanks for calling and, Sage.

Thank you.
Councilmembers.
My name is Raymond Evans and I work with gig workers in Seattle.
I worked in merchant for 22 years at a high end clientele who served in multiple capacities and the local native of Seattle.
The city has always been a place that I could relate to.
As a black gay mail, the city's changing face and I feel like we are leaving people behind.

The gig work is a nice fallback to allow people of color, black, Brown, whatever color you may be, to have a way to obtain a life for themselves.
Come to a city that's a wonderful place, pursue a life.
When we are doing work as gig workers, large companies are making billions of dollars in profits, we are the person that has undergone through, and trying to make an contributor to society.
To continue to rely on the Graciousness of others are also stressed.
We fall through the cracks.
People are making three dollars or four dollars per hour.
We can't paper Mentzer license fees amendments.

It's imperative that the city Council, I encourage the city Council, to consider voting on this bill today from transparency so that we can set up a better understanding of what these corporations are really doing so that Seattle can continue to be a city which is based in values, diversity, Multicultural, ethnic somebody, black lives matter.
I would encourage you guys today to make that happen and thank you for your time.
Thank you for calling in today.
Next up is Kim Wolf, followed by Aaron.
Thank you.
I am a gig worker and I am supporting the passage of CB 120069.
Also because of the transparency that is in there because it is the first step that we need.
In order to know what exactly is happening and make sure that their standards are there for everyone.
Also, the commitment to pass fair labor standards, or pay standards, this year is a thing that I am most excited about.
I really hope that you guys get this passed today.
I can see the rest of my time.
Thank you for calling and.
Next up is Aaron followed by Michelle Thomas.
Hi, I am a project manager with the lead programs in the Southwest area of King County which includes the Southwest present that opened operations in December.
I'm here to talk about funding L.E.A.D.
To bridge a gap to meet the needs of our community.
In the Southwest Precinct, we have a great relationship working with area organizations, residents and business owners.
The letter of which are particularly excited about L.E.A.D .'s arriving to West Seattle.
Asking all the time what can we do to help.
They are also asking in what ways they might be able to help them.

With the $3 million funding gap, we are asking businesses and residents for their patience, even though we have an important group who can help us prevent people from landing in the criminal justice system.

Filling the gap will not only provide us with resources in terms of case management we need for the program to be successful, but it will allow our community as well to participate in a program that prevents harm to the clients that we serve and impacts to the surrounding area.
Thank you very much.
Thanks for calling in, Aaron.
Next up is Michelle Thomas followed by Mariah Mitchell.
Hi.
I'm with the Washington low income housing alliance Testifying with strong support for the Concurrency ordinance before you today.

Including the commitment to take action to enact a minimum compensation quality for gig workers the ship the city and state has taken steps to expand tenant protections and address our affordable housing crisis.
We have to do more.
Including by raising pay for gig workers who are some of the lowest paid workers in our city.
According to the latest out of reach report from the National low income housing coalition, workers need a job paying more than $40 per hour to afford a two bedroom apartment in King County.
Tens of thousands of jobs via Apps like Instacart and door dash pay as little as two dollars per job.
Far less than minimum wage.
This is directly related to housing justice and the current Eviction crisis.
Economic security is housing security.
When people get paid a living wage, they can afford to pay the rent.
This is also about racial justice and creating a marketable recovery from the pandemic.
Bipoc workers are highly represented as both gig workers and as Renters.
Bipoc Renters disproportionately face housing insecurity and emissions.
Fair and decent wages for gig workers is critical for racial justice and housing stability.
I urge you to pass the transparency ordinance today with a commitment to take actions this year to end the sub minimum wage for gig workers . Thank you.
Thank you so much for calling him.
Next up is Mariah Mitchell followed by Jason.
Mariah, I see that your Un- muted on my end, but we cannot hear you.
Check to see if your Un-Muted on your phone.

Okay, so my name is Mariah Mitchell and I am calling in for the transparency today.
I would like to say that I am a family member of Charlena Liles, and I also grew up by the North precinct.
I am very familiar with the racism that comes out of that Precinct, but the reason I'm calling today is with working Washington, and I'm calling on the transparency.
I'm a single mom of three, and this last year I've had to make the hard choices of whether to stay at home to help my children with schoolwork, or bring in some income.
My eldest child would likely stay at home in order to help the family out so that I could work as an Uber each driver.
Instead of being able to attend her own activities, and the companies I have worked for both the ability to make a flexible schedule for ourselves, yet penalize us when daily life happens.
Establishing labor standards for gig workers would ensure transparency continued flexibility, access and stability, and overall enrichment of our lives.
It would also set equity standards for all, so that nobody is getting paid less than minimum wage.
When I first started working, the pay was great.
I could do this.
They cut our pay time and time again.
Currently without the hazard pay.
The pay is substandard and you can't live off of two dollars.
Along with that they have done unfair background checks and also have deactivated us without giving us a reason.
You must create labor standards with full transparency for all gig workers.
Thank you.
Thank you for calling in.

Welcome.
Thank you for having me.
This actually marks my second year coming to the city Council and I again am also with working Washington.
I been coming here for two years asking for city Council to back us up with minimum wage standards and transparency.
Help us truly keep making money out there like Mariah said.
We have seen pay cut after pay cut after pay cut while their revenues and other stock prices and Whatnot go up and up and up.
It's all because of us.
We are out there making work happen.
We need you guys to back us up because it's obviously--when they have the chance to make laws themselves, they make them themselves and they make it at the expense of the worker.
Who is actually the best resource.
Seattleites, we can do better than asking for the last two years.
Come on, let's get this right, let's do it now.
Pass minimum wage standards with transparency is a step in the right direction, but we need to keep going.
Happy Tua anniversary.
Thank you for calling in today.

Hi, I am a project manager for L.E.A.D.
In Seattle.
I'm here to provide thanks to the Council for today's proposed amendment of Council the 120096.
That will fill L.E.A.D .'s 2021 budget deficit.
This will mean that we will continue to provide desperately needed Wraparound case management services for individuals most traditionally impacted by the criminal legal system.
That will work to address the underlying needs contributing to this behavior.

This means that we can continue employing our case management team, including Bipoc individuals and individuals with lived experience we have dedicated their careers to building this incredible difficult and rewarding work.
We can continue responding to community members and Stakeholders requests for a response that is not traditional enforcement to address low-level public order concerns.
Thank you.
Thank you for calling in today.

Begin on other items of business on the agenda.

Council bill 120097 for the week of May 31st, 2021 through June 4TH, 2021 and ordering the payment thereof.
Thank you, I moved to pass Council bill 120097.

Second.

Eight in favor, none opposed.

Agenda item 1, council bill 120096.

Relating to appropriations for the human services Department amending ordinance 126237 which adopted the 2021 budget modifying a proviso imposed by ordinance 126298 and ratifying and confirming certain prior acts.
Thank you, Madam clerk.
I moved to pass Council bill 120096.
Is there a second?
Second.
Thank you so much, Councilmember Lewis, you are the prime sponsor.
I'm going to hand it over to you to address the side of.
Payment thank you so much, Madam President.
I want to thank the folks that called in in support of this bill.
Particularly Mr. Dearborn who really has been out in the field doing incredible work.
Moving our neighbors expense homelessness into well Resourced and supported hotel day shelters.

That have been making a difference for the folks who are receiving that kind of shelter and care, as well as the housed residents and business owners of those neighborhoods who have had problematic experiences with some of the Unsanctioned Encampments.
This legislation gets us one step closer to continuing to hold up those folks who are doing this work by giving them the resources they need to get it done.
To accomplish a lot of resolutions in these complicated areas to the benefit of all parties.
We are really making sure that we are centering that fundamentally we all have the same interests.

That's really the core I think of they just care model and why it has been so successful, is really leveling that someone experiencing homelessness and Unsanctioned Encampments, business owners and residents that concerns about the contentment, ultimately all have the same interest at heart, which is actually being able to move folks inside to get the care and assistance they need.

This is the model that we are essentially committing to Frontloading more Resourced for in the run up here to the reopening of Seattle's economy and the reality that during Covid as we have seen in countless new story Commas, the resources to provide Healthcare, shelter, and care to our homeless neighbors have been the most impacted to a large extent, by the reality of the Covid emergency.
That rebuilding and building back after Covid is going to require filling a lot of the service gaps, which means leaning into models like the just care model.
I want to thank the downtown Seattle Association for the very strong support of this measure.
Seattle metropolitan Chamber of Commerce, in addition to the service providers who have been doing this work, particularly the defender Association.
Obviously reach, chief Seattle Club, Asian Council and referral service among others.

I hope that we can get the support out the door to continue to build on the progress that we have been making together, and have that impact felt and more parts of the city instead of just in the Chinatown I.D.
And Pioneer square neighborhoods.
With that, I will turn it over because I think there are some amendments that need to be considered as well.
Appreciate the opportunity to cure this up.
Thank you so much, Councilmember Lewis for addressing the base bill.
There is at least one amendment that I'm aware of.
So, we will go ahead and address that amendment and then once we've addressed the amendment, we can open up the debate and discussion to the bill as amended.
So, I'm going to recognize Councilmember Herbold who has amendment one in order to have her make her motion.
Thank you so much.
I moved to amend Council bill 120096 as presented as amendment one on the agenda.
Second.
It has been moved and Seconded that the bill be amended as presented on amendment one Councilmember Herbold, back to you as the prime sponsor so that you can walk us through the amendment.
Thank you so much.
As I mentioned at this morning's briefing, this amendment provides $3 million of the $12 billion to expand the city's contract with L.E.A.D ..
This expanded contract will allow L.E.A.D.
To respond to the increase in community referrals as a result of Covid, and increased cost of operating during the pandemic.
The expanded contract is consistent with councils vote last year to require L.E.A.D.

To accept community referrals without prior law enforcement approval, and Council's adoption of resolution 31916 and 2019 which declares the city's commitment to ensuring that law enforcement Prearrest diversion programs received public funding sufficient to accept all priority qualifying referrals citywide.
Why is the removal of the barrier to referrals requiring prior law enforcement approval relevant to this amendment?
It is so important because our community Stakeholders want to use L.E.A.D ..
We got rid of the barrier that limited Nonlaw enforcement referrals, now we need to address the capacity limitations.
Otherwise, L.E.A.D.
Will not be able to take direct referrals from as many neighborhood groups, neighborhood watch's rethink advisory councils, and business improvement areas that are interested in using L.E.A.D ..
I want to thank Councilmember Lewis and Councilmember Morales for their Cosponsorship of this amendment and urge it's support.
Thank you.
Thank you so much, Councilmember Herbold.
Councilmember Morales.
You have your hand raised.
Shall we vote on this first or can I just address the amendment?
What's that?
Do you want to vote on the amendment first or is this a time for me to address a question mark to now would be the time to address and make sure you make any comments related to the amendment.
First, I do want to thank Councilmember Herbold for allowing me to cosponsor this.
She beat me to the punch on actually drafting this amendment.
There is so much interest in this sponsoring this because we know that L.E.A.D.
Works.
It is providing the organization, the effort is providing consistent valuable diversion services.
The L.E.A.D.
Program partners with organizations who know our communities and understand the different points of view that our neighbors feel about how to best address the challenges of our homeless neighbors.

But, they are also, informed and they are trusted by community members, by our Un- housed neighbors, business owners, so it's really important as Councilmember Herbold said that we increase the capacity of this group to respond and provide the kind of service that we need.
Constituents in my community are regularly asking how we can expand L.E.A.D.
In places like mt . Baker and beacon Hill.

So, I'm really excited to be able to cosponsor this amendment and look forward to our ability as a city to make the kind of investments we need to really begin addressing the challenges that our homeless neighbors are facing.
Thank you so much.
Councilmember Morales for those comments.
I see that Councilmember Pedersen also has his hand raised.
I'm assuming he wants to make a comment on amendment one
Thank you, Council President.
I strongly support the L.E.A.D.
Diversion program and will continue to fund L.E.A.D ..
I would rather proceed 100% of these funds go toward housing people experiencing homelessness.
I'll be voting no on this amendment which would redirect 25% of the $12 million.
Thank you.
Thank you, Councilmember Pedersen.
Any other comments or questions on amendment one?
I don't see any other hands raised, so with that being said, will the clerk please call the roll on the adoption of amendment one?
Lewis?
Aye.
Morales?
Yes.
Pedersen?
No.
Sawant?
Yes.
Strauss?
Yes.
Herbold?
Yes.
Juarez?
Aye.
Council President Gonzalez?
Aye.
Seven in favor, one opposed.
Thank you so much, the motion carries, the amendment is adopted, and the amended bill is now before the Council.
Are there any additional comments on the amended bill?
Councilmember Morales, please.
Thank you.
I am really excited to see this bill, so I do want to thank Councilmember Lewis.
My office consistently hears resounding support for just care.
In fact just care is the model that my office looked to last year when we fought to eliminate the navigation team, and replace it with the hope program.

I will admit there is still some work to do to make sure that the hope program is implemented as intended, but just care has proven to be successful at sheltering people in safe, Non-Congregant settings.
At providing intensive 24/7 case management and in finding people long-term stable housing.
They are not perpetuating trauma to Un-Housed people.
We know that to truly meet each individual's needs, we need this kind of service, this kind of option for folks.
That's why my constituents are regularly asking for programs like this to be extended.
That support comes because people are seeing rapid results, and they are seeing real results.

Weather we'll talk about small business owners having fewer encounters with folks who are experiencing a crisis, or service providers who are seeing a real collaboration pay off, we know that housed neighbors are seeing folks committing crimes of poverty or crimes related to a state of distress getting the kind of help that they need.
And, we see Un-Housed folks able to get into a safe space, receive intensive services that meet their needs, and find housing.

So, small business owners, business associations, service providers, housed neighbors, the King County Council, the majority of the city Council, and most importantly, our Un- housed neighbors themselves have all applauded the work of just care.
I was recently in public safety meeting in the Cid were a representative from SPD said they too welcomed the work that just care does.
So, I don't know who isn't on board at this point, but I think this is really important work that goes beyond traditional outreach.
This is public safety work that doesn't involve the police.
It's substance abuse treatment work, crisis intervention work, and it is housing connection and support work.
There is a real appetite for us to do something on all of these fronts.
That's a big part of the conversation we have been having in the last year in Seattle.
I have heard it over and over again that folks want this work done without police intervention.
Without punitive consequences that move people from one place to the other, but don't actually accomplish anything.
People understand that that doesn't work.
Showing up with a chuck, a Bulldozer, or a dump truck, isn't humane.
This is an option that really provides a model of care that has acute impacts for our community with minimal funds and support from the city.
They have been able to create a system that really has huge support across the city.
I'm excited by the funds that we have appropriated, and am excited to see this work continue.
I'll just close by thanking both L.E.A.D.
And just care for the work they've done in my district.
Thanking Councilmember Lewis once again for highlighting the needs of these programs and Council colleagues who have cosponsor this.
I think it's our strong advocacy that is contributing to this work.
I look forward to having a strong partner in the executive office so that we can distribute funds allocated for just care in the future.
As we all know, we can appropriate these funds, but we need to get the money to the providers.
My hope is that we will be able to do that once we get this signed.
Thank you.
Thank you so much, Councilmember Morales.
Really appreciate those comments.
Councilmember Strauss.
Thank you, Council president and thank you colleagues and sponsors of this bill for bring it forward.
I'm excited to vote yesterday and hope to see this bill sooner.
I'm glad to see it here today because we know that just care works.
It is a proven solution to address homelessness with lasting results rather than Time-Limited results.
This is a program that we need throughout the city.
I'm excited to see how we, and how quickly we can expand the services because we need these services.
We need the just care program in green Lake and Fremont and Ballard, and throughout the city.
Thank you to everyone who has made it a success so far and I look forward to continuing to work with everyone on bringing just care throughout the city.
Thank you, Council President.
Thank you so much Councilmember Strauss.
Councilmember Lewis.
I see you have the hand raised.
You are the prime sponsor so you will get last word.
Let me see if anyone else has any comments.
Councilmember Pedersen, please.
Thank you, Council President.
I had a question about, based on some comments I just heard, some questions of the sponsor about the bill and then quick comments, just a few sentences.
The question I have, we talk about just care.
I just want to make sure what we are talking about is the model, and not a particular vendor or provider.
Is that correct?
That could be one way that it could be interpreted.
We can't be too prescriptive.
The bill does not pick a particular vendor, right?
Not necessarily, but the people that have been bidding on this work have been the same consortium of providers.
So, I would anticipate that it would probably end up being the consortium that the defender Association has convened.
It doesn't necessarily have to be.
Thank you.
Council President, just a quick comment to close out.
Thank you.
I'll be voting yes on this ordinance.
I recognized the urgent need to house people experiencing homelessness.
Placing them in hotels and other Non-Congregant shelter during the Covid pandemic is a promising, albeit temporary, solution during the current crisis.

I'm supporting this investment of public dollars to make sure the investment of these public dollars is ultimately effective, regardless of which service providers get the funds, since this is not a Sole- source award.
I would ask our human services Department to track the key Metrics such as the cost to house each person, and the key outcomes, such as the number of people Exiting to permanent housing.
I'll be voting yes on this.
Thank you.
Thank you so much, Councilmember Pedersen.
Any additional comments before we close out debate?
I'm not seeing any other hands raised.
I also wanted to echo thanks to Councilmember Lewis for leading the charge as the chair of our homelessness committee.
Really appreciate the leadership in this space and the opportunity to collaborate with you, Councilmember Lewis.
As one of the sponsors of this really important piece of legislation.

We know that the model related to meeting the needs of people experiencing homelessness, that allows us to be nimble and not pursue sort of strategies that are law enforcement focused first, are really critical to our ability to successfully end homelessness and while this is a temperate solution, it is still a very important one to begin to connect people to the services and the housing that they need.
So, I'm really excited about the opportunity to continue to invest in a model that really seems to have broad community support amongst constituencies that don't ordinarily agree with each other.
I think that the results that we are seeing from housing placements and service connection are very promising results.

I'm excited to be able to continue to support investments, strategic investments in this area to continue to make a meaningful difference in the area of homelessness . with that being said, I am going to hand it over to Councilmember Lewis, who is going to close out debate and then we are going to vote on this bill.
Thank you, Madam President.
I'll be brief here in closing it out.
Given everyone else's comments.
I've said it a couple times that I had a predecessor that used to have passing the C test.
It's an important component.
People that can see the tangible difference that something that we fund as having.
Then, draw conclusions about whether that is making a difference in their lives are not.
Unequivocally, this just care consortium during the pandemic has passed the see test.

I receive more positive communication from provider advocates small business owners, from neighborhood residents, who are involved in this and to have really changed some of their core conditions and perceptions about how to solve the homelessness crisis through their expense of working with and interacting with just care.
Seeing how this approach and this model can work.
I just wanted to add a couple more sort of logistical things at the top.
There are many ways that this investment can be squared with our ultimate budget.

I know this has been a little bit of a hiccup in funding this effort over the passed--over the course of the passed few months, based on interpretations of FEMA guidance and based on schedules of potential reimbursement for some of these dollars.
We have new information now that we didn't have when we initially passed this legislation.
We know that the general fund is recovering at a faster rate than we had initially anticipated when we did our last budget we have the benefit of a $10 million FEMA reimbursement insurance program.
Represented Macri passed in the last legislative session.
We have the benefit of knowing that there is going to be another big tranche of Federal money coming down the pipeline in 2022 that gives us some extra flexibility.
Even since crafting this bill, we also have a little bit more assurance that Jumpstart is going to survive its legal challenges and be part of the fabric of our city budget.
There are ways we can square this obligation.
Of $12 million.

That can be spent up front at the beginning of the summer, to make a noticeable difference and impact both for people experiencing homelessness, and people who have concerned about the Unsanctioned Encampments.
There are multiple ways we can remit this money.
The legislation allows for this money to be remitted through the contracts that King County has.

There would still be subject to the same reporting requirements but to take advantage of our relationship and partnership with King County to remit those dollars faster to get them out into the community.

From my conversations with our counterparts at King County, that arrangement would be possible, if it is something the city needs to pursue to avoid administrative hurdles with are greatly appreciated and considerably overworked human services Department contractors.
King County stands ready to be a strong partner, and I look forward to helping to establish that relationship if necessary to get this resource out into the community.
I do want to just finally think the coalition that Councilmember Gonzalez alluded to earlier.

This effort has led to a letter that is now out in the world in the public record, where the Chamber of Commerce and the downtown Seattle Association appraising Councilmember Sawant for her leadership.

I want to thank the coalition that includes a downtown Seattle Association, and the Seattle Chamber of Commerce, in addition to organizations representing arts, tourism, and service providers who have been clamoring for this kind of investment for a long time.

As mentioned this morning and Council briefing, we addressed many of the concerns of Stakeholders and the office of labor standards through a substitute bill.
And an amendment that were both adopted in Committee, just moving backwards a little bit for some context first before I get into the details of that substitute bill and amendment.
Misclassification is a high priority of our labor standards advocates.
Myself included.
Back in February, 2019, after working with the office of labor standards, the council passed resolution 31863.

In part, that resolution requested that the labor standards advisory Council work with the office of labor standards on the issue of Misclassification and provide input on effective strategies based on their experience in existing worker and business associations.
In May, 2020, the Council received final recommendations.
However, due to the pandemic we were not able to take up the recommendations early this year when my staff and Council central staff presented to them on the plans to take up their recommendations.
Again, that policy deliberation began, I believe it was back in February.
The Finance and housing committee proceeded to have several committee discussions on the legislation.
Which led to additional conversations, and other Stakeholders.
Finally on June 4TH, the committee adopted a substitute bill to address the concerns that we heard throughout the process.
Again, just very broadly, the bill includes a timely payment obligation for folks who are considered independent contractors.

Not every person who is considered an independent contractor has been misclassified, but the timely payment obligation should be obligations that all workers receive, whether or not they work for an employer or are independently contracted.

Then, also, the other obligations in the bill, obligations that require advanced notice to a contract employee about what the conditions are for which they will be receiving payment on the front end, and then on the back end, and explanation of why your payment--labor standards regular employees I think take for granted.
In the area of our independent contracting, these are not standard obligations.
It's kind of information that an independent contractor looks at to help them determine whether or not there being misclassified as an independent contractor.
It allows them to either advocate for themselves as a worker.
The changes in the bill that were in the substitute that we discussed last week, clarifies that the director of Ols has authority to issue rules for the enforcement of this legislation.
There are some categories of independent workers that have rule issuance authority will allow Ols to take a look at.
Clearly as was always intended with the bill, not cover independent contractors when the only relationship between the contractor and the hiring entity is a rent agreement.
That is intended to deal with concerns that we've heard from independent contractor Hairstylists whose only relationship with a salon is renting a space for work.
It moves the effective date of the legislation to September 20, 2022 at office of labor standards request.
It adds a Non-Codified session related to the standard that exists for the office of labor standards to request funding through the budget process, directly of the Council.

This is a special authority that the Ols director has, unlike many departments of the city, to establish their authority so that they can directly identify what their budget needs are, and I have to go through the Mayor's office.
This is the way that the Council and the Mayor will deliberate on the enforcement costs associated with this bill.
It removes platform workers from many aspects of the bill.
Although not for timely payment, those obligations still exist.
This was an amendment that Councilmember Strauss requested that I raise in his committee last weekend.
In committee last week.
Which I did so.
It was included in the substitute on his request.

Finally, and learning with the removal of platform dig workers from many of the aspects of the bill, it also States our interest as I Council on establishing minimum compensation and other protections like transparency for dig workers.
From late September to the end of 2021 that covers the bulk.
If there are comments about it, Madam chair, happy to open it up.
I would like to some closing thanks before we call the vote.
Payment absolutely.
Colleagues, any other comments?

Agenda item 13, council bill 120092 related to regulation of food delivery businesses and platforms, adding a new chapter 7.30 to the Seattle Miscible code.
The committee recommends the bill pass.
Thank you so much.
This is a bill that I have primarily sponsored.
I do want to give Councilmember Morales, as the chair of the committee an opportunity to make comments on the bill.
Before I do.

I am really excited to have an opportunity to bring forward Council bill 120092.
The fair food delivery bill.
I believe this bill is going to be instrumental in helping restaurants by ensuring their presence on delivery platforms is in their hands, and their control.
That it can continue to own the guest experience from beginning to end.
The guest expenses something restaurants worked very hard to build and execute.

When restaurants are unwilling participants on a delivery platform that creates space for errors, mistakes and Misfires, that can and do affect the restaurant, and also negatively impact the delivery driver when a customer has a negative experience.
It is my hope that this will also help delivery drivers by allowing them to just focus on the delivery of food.

When a restaurant is unable to participate, there may be an old, out of date menu Online for example, drivers become, the customer effectively and have to make an order on behalf of customers that they are bringing food to.

So, this entire process of ordering, waiting for food, getting the flu to its delivery access, takes a lot of time and of course reduces income for a driver who has little or no protections or benefits.

This is especially made worse as this process can mean a lot of places were in order fails to meet expectations for customers despite being well executed by the people at the restaurant or the driver who brought the food to the customer.
Driver should not have to suffer financially because of this, nor should restaurants take the hit when they have no idea that a customer is ordering from an out of date menu.

Other businesses across the city have shared similar issues and experiences with platforms, some of those businesses include--my office in developing this legislation engaged with working Washington, teamsters, hospitality groups we also engaged with representatives from the delivery platforms directly and have also heard directly from of the restaurants, all of whom have expressed broad support for this piece of legislation.
This legislation is very narrowly focused.
On ensuring restaurants are willing participants in the delivery food world.
Which we know now, and pandemic life, is become the new normal for so many of us here in Seattle.

It is my hope that this bill will help improve and streamline the process of ordering for customers, making the food reflective of an Up-To- date menu, and that delivery drivers can just focus on Pickups and making deliveries.

So, I'm really excited about having an opportunity to bring this forward to Y'all, and I want to thank everybody who was on the committee who voted in favor of recommending that the full council passes legislation.
I also want to thank my senior policy adviser and our Council central staff for their amazing policy work on this legislation.
With that college, I hope you'll join me in supporting restaurants by voting yes on Council bill 120092.
Any additional comments?

Eight in favor, none opposed.
The bill passes, and the chair will sign it.
